characters: WE FOLLOW A PAIR OF DINERS AS THEY ENTER,
THAT FILLS THE SPECTACULAR RING, AND LIKE A CLOUD RISING,
WHAT TRANSPIRES OVER THE NEXT SEVEN ROUNDS IS AN
OUT ON HIS FEET, AND BARELY ABLE TO RAISE HIS FIST, ROCKY
MASON SUDDENLY GETS A SURGE OF ADRENALINE AND UNLEASHES A
BEAUTIFUL SIX PUNCH COMBINATION THAT ROCKS ROCKY BADLY.
PROVIDE A PATCHWORK QUILT OF THE CITY OF PHILADELPHIA. HE
ROCKY LOOKS TO HIS CORNER AND SEES THE SPECTRE OF MICKEY.
SEE ROCKY GOING THROUGH AN EXTRAORDINARILY GRUELING AND
THE ATMOSPHERE IS SUPER-CHARGED AS HIGH ROLLERS ARE STILL
CORNERS AND INTO THE INCREDIBLE HEAT OF BATTLE.
UNBELIEVABLY IN A GESTURE OF RESPECT THEY TAP GLOVES.
FLOOR AND ROCKY IS SENT CRASHING TO THE CANVAS
EXCHANGING PUNCH FOR PUNCH WITH BALBOA.
AS THE MUSIC BEGINS TO SWELL
LUNGES BACK JUST AS THE BELL RINGS.
ROCKY REJOINS HIS SON AND FAMILY AND SWIRLING HUMANITY
BREATH AS HE LOOKS OUT OVER A SEA OF ROOFTOPS THAT
THE BELL RINGS AND THE WARRIORS CHARGE OUT OF THEIR
SUDDENLY MASON EXPLODES WITH A RIGHT HOOK THROWN FROM THE
IN THE GYM HE IS PUT THROUGH DIFFICULT MANEUVERS DESIGNED
ROCKY SMILES AND STARTS TO WALK AWAY AND THEN PAUSES, RE-
PUNISHMENT AND SPINNING AWAY, LITERALLY STANDS TOE-TO-TOE
WITH THE LAST OF HIS STRENGTH, BALBOA DRIVES A SERIES OF
AT THE TOP OF THE HISTORICAL STADIUM ROCKY GASPS FOR
FILTERING INTO THEIR FRONT ROW SEATS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scene arises on a STARK GRACEFUL VISUAL of TWO BOXERS engaged in combat...the dominant fighter, known as MASON ‘THE LINE’ DIXON moves in for the kill. His body language is fluid, and boxing skills are pure precision savagery. In EXTREME SLOW motion Dixon feints and throws A THUNDEROUS BLOW that crashes with devastating results against his opponent’s chin. A surrendering towel is tossed into the air as the challenger begins an UNCONSCIOUS DESCENT TO THE CANVAS, Dixon strides to his corner, ONE VICTORIOUS FIST held high. The haunting scene begins to melt away as an ascending chorus of boos fills the arena.

dialogues.speaker: COMMENTATOR
dialogues.text: ++-This crowd is not holding back its anger over this latest debacle. The SCREEN now transforms from BLACK AND WHITE INTO SUBTLE COLOR.

dialogues.speaker: COMMENTATOR
dialogues.text: ++-In what has become an all too regular occurrence ~ Another inferior opponent rendered unconscious. A LARGE CUP OF ICE is heaved from several rows back SPRAYING Mason and his entourage. Another CUP OF ICE descends into the ring nearly hitting a member of Dixon’s corner who stands behind the champion brazenly holding the CHAMPIONSHIP BELT high over his head. The camera work grows increasingly aggressive, matching the flustered crowd's attitude, COMMENTATOR #2 (CONT ‘D) Objects are being thrown into the ring! Cubes of ice hit DIXON!

dialogues.speaker: COMMENTATOR
dialogues.text: ---Another disappointing title defense -— Something hit Dixon! An EMPTY BEER BOTTLE descends from high up in the bleachers and crashes with lethal impact on the canvas. The twenty or so people in the ring panic, shielding their heads while frantically scanning the crowd. The booing increases. Dixon climbs through the ropes. Then he pauses. He glares defiantly at the crowd.  COMMENTATOR #1 (CONT’D) The champ Mason Dixon is leaving - This is a horrible scene. Dixon wants no more! The crowd is growing more aggressive at this lackluster event. It was just a matter of time before all Hell broke loose! As the CREDITS ROLL we follow DIXON and his entourage out of the arena followed by RABID JEERING. Over the chorus of insults, the simple scene DISSOLVES TO PHILADELPHIA‘S WATERFRONT. EXT. — CITY-SCAPE - PHILADELPHIA ~ DUSK Wide view ACROSS THE DELAWARE RIVER, settling on the working side of the Philadelphia waterfront. We see LARGE FREIGHTERS laden with cargo while other ships are being towed to moorings. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: EXT.
dialogues.text: Traveling inland, the camera comes to rest on an elevated shot of a LARGE HISTORICAL GRAVEYARD that overlooks the river. TOMBSTONES rise and fall in ever-undulating GRAVE sites. Seated on an old folding chair is ROCKY BALBOA. Several yards away, staring in the opposite direction is PAULI. His eyes are heavy with grief as he glances back at ROCKY, who appears to be speaking, but not loud enough to be audible,

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: The ex-fighter stares at the headstone that reads:

dialogues.speaker: DIED JUNE 11, 2002
dialogues.text: A FRESH DISPLAY OF FLOWERS has been placed upon the headstone.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: Obviously uncomfortable being there, faces his brother-in law.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: «».It‘’s soon gettin’ dark. ROCKY gestures he is not done; a moment later, he rises, kisses the headstone and with a sense of emotional weariness, folds his chair and crosses to PAULIE,.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: ++.Time goes by too fast.

dialogues.speaker: PAULTE
dialogues.text: ++-Not fast enough. They begin to move off among the growing evening shadows. PAULIE (CONT’D) Where’s the kid? He shoulda been here.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (low) ~ It's all right.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: It ain’t all right.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: ++-He gets busy.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: He don’t get that ‘busy’

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: ++-Let’s not talk about it here, Paulie. They walk a short distance - A distant ship horn is heard. ROCKY (CONT’D) Ya goin’ tonight?

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: (defensively) I’m workin’ - I took ‘the tour’ the last three years.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: C’mon.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: I got responsibilities.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Just a few hours.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: -+-Lemme think about it. The two men move away in strained silence as ROCKY takes a fleeting glance at Adrian’s burial site. EXT. - ROCKY’S NEIGHBORHOOD - NIGHTFALL Several quick cuts of THE NEIGHBORHOOD. MIXED GROUPS of youths play basketball under a simple streetlight... Random shots of street activity. EXT. — HOAGIE SHOP — DUSK In front of a window that spells out in neon “Atomic Hoagie Shop,” we see several tough Asian youths clustered together. cur TO: EXT. - THE “ROCKY’S” RESTAURANT -— NIGHT It’s located on a FAIRLY COMMERCIAL STREET in South Philadelphia - A signature RED NEON SIGN hangs over a simple entrance.

dialogues.speaker: WE FOLLOW A PAIR OF DINERS AS THEY ENTER,
dialogues.text: The diners are greeted by a Latina hostess/waitress, ISABEL, approximately thirty years of age. She is seven months pregnant. The camera reveals twenty tables. Near the door is a MODEST BAR, decorated with SPORTS MEMORABILIA. Painted over the room’s LARGEST WALL is a bold but aging MURAL of ROCKY’S MEMORABLE BATTLE WITH APOLLO CREED.  The SEPIA-TONED MURAL is reminiscent of THE FAMOUS MURAL IN JACK DEMPSEY’S RESTAURANT ONCE LOCATED IN TIME SQUARE. ISABEL the PREGNANT hostess seats the new arrivals. The CAMERA follows her as she enters the kitchen. Four men of LATIN HERITAGE work to service the orders. ROCKY is helping cook A PAIR OF TENDERLOINS. ROCKY’s at a WALL PHONE. He dials.

dialogues.speaker: ROCRY
dialogues.text: How we doin’?

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: Okay - Except for the freebees. ISABEL nods towards a couple of well-worn ex~fighters seated near the kitchen, having a free dinner. The phone rings and an ANSWERING MACHINE clicks on.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT JR.
dialogues.text: (not confident) Hi, no one’s home - Please leave your number and I'll call you back...thanks

dialogues.speaker: MACHINE VOICE
dialogues.text: The mailbox for this number is full. Please try again later. ROCKY exhales, disappointed. Hangs up. The hostess approaches.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: Table six is askin’ for you - They wanna hear a ‘story.’

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (dully) Ain‘t they heard ‘em all?

dialogues.speaker: HOSTESS
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Keeps ‘em coming back. ROCKY removes his worn blazer from a hook. The blazer is the industrial quality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, keep takin’ that olive oil - The kid‘ll be born very strong. (exits)

dialogues.speaker: DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: ROCKY sits at a TABLE OF SIX WELL-INTENTIONED GUIDOS FROM NEW JERSEY.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: ++-I went in like an animal, an’ pushed him into the corner an unloaded everything I had - Hook, hook, an’ three rights, an’ Creed kept bustin’ me back pretty good - Then I heard the best sound I had heard in my life - the bell... The diners laugh. ROCKY (CONT’D) Y'know, I ain’t never been so tired an’ I was tryin’ to figure out how to survive the last round, then, yeah, then I heard Mickey’s voice come into my ear “You can go this - Get out there and fight this goy hard ya bum! {laughs )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the residence of WORLD CHAMPION, MASON DIXON...lights emanate from the large windows... Downstairs 7 MEMBERS OF HIS POSSE party hard. The MUSIC tears a hole in the night. cUuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: INT.
dialogues.text: Alone in the dark room, we see MASON DIXON seated in a modern armchair looking at a LARGE SCREEN. On the screen are the final moments of his LAST TITLE DEFENSE.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP —- PLASMA SCREEN The AUDIENCE REACTS WITH DISDAIN.

dialogues.speaker: COMMENTATOR
dialogues.text: There’s just no decent competition —~ Fans are not going to pay good money to see these one-sided affairs anymore! - It’s a virtual wasteland with Dixon, who I believe is a solid fighter, surrounded by an ocean of nobodies! Multiple shots of the audience heaving cups of ice into the ring. DIXON appears incensed, yet troubled.

dialogues.speaker: COMMENTATOR
dialogues.text: - There’s an old saying in boxing. The fortunes of the sport ride on the shoulders of the heavyweight champion - The way things are going, this sport’s facing slow and agonizing demise. MASON DIXON cannot mask his dejection. INT./EXT. ROCKY’S RESTAURANT — (ALLEY) ~ NIGHT ROCKY has one foot in the door and the other in the alley as he turns out all the INTERIOR LIGHTS. Finally the small NEON SIGN reading “ROCKY'S” clicks off. Locking up, he departs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The LOADING DOCK area is completely deserted. WOODEN PALLETS are stacked obtusely against the BRICK FACADE. Pools of light emanate from bare bulbs peeking beneath rusted metal shades directly above each LOADING BAY. A light colored THREE YEAR OLD FORD van is parked near the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I told ya I can‘t - I got responsibilities.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: C’mon, we do it every year.  INT. - SHAMROCK MEAT HOUSE - OLD GYM. ROCKY and PAULIE walk beneath a conveyer belt of hooks. Paulie is garbed in a gray industrial suit. His NAME Is INSCRIBED above his pocket. In the background is a fit, diligent 30 year old, East Indian employee named RAVI.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: »«.T can’t, Rocko.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Sure ya can.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: Iocan’t - (turns) Hey, Ravi, (unfriendly) Who’s watchin’ the East Side?

dialogues.speaker: RAVI
dialogues.text: I checked it 15 minutes ago.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: (annoyed) Ya like movin’ around fast, don't ya? RAVI moves off. PAULIE (CONT’D) (towards Ravi) Wise guy - (to Rocky). Didn’t I say last year was it?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Ya did, but I want ya with me.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: If this place gets robbed, who’s blamed? Me.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Coupla hours - It’s good talkin’ about the old days.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: Sometimes talkin’ the ‘old day’s stuff’ ain’t so good -— (glances back at Ravi) Y'know, it’s gettin’ depressin’.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is?

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: (gestures toward Ravi) I’m here almost thirty friggin’ years an’ they're groomin’ a goofy guy who grew up scrubbin’ elephants to take my job. (Rocky begins to object) So what’s the problem? Ya don’t like bein’ alone?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: You heard...

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: See ya around. ROCKY shakes his head in disappointment and starts to move off. PAULIE feels a slight pang of guilt.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: Yo...A couple hours, that’s it. EXT./INT. — OLD GYM ~ NIGHT - (LAS VEGAS) DIXON'S BLACK S.U.V. WITH 22 INCH RIMS pulls up. He enters. It’s fairly late and a few hopeless OLD TIMERS listlessly train. MASON walks up to an old Black trainer named MARTIN. He is holding a cane.

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: You’re always here, aren't ya? OLD MARTIN stiffly faces DIXON.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: ++-How you doin’ young man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men sit alone on a well-worn set of wooden BLEACHERS...In the background an older fighter hits a heavy bag.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: If money’s not doin’ it for ya, what is? - ‘Cause ya know all them people around you is there ‘cause of the money, when that’s gone, they gone too - You knowin’ what ya need since you was ten, since ya walked yourseif in here alone.

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: Just wanna feel good - Be proud about somethin’.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: ++-You go along with other people's thinkin’ ~- Who’s fault is it? Reapin’ what you sow. Once people made up their minds about what a man is, usually ain’t never change that, no, but changin’ the way ya thinkin’ about yaself ~- Ain’t never too late for that.

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: (confused) But why I gotta care? ~ I got everythin’ Why I gotta care?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Cause ya got everythin’ money can buy - ‘cept what it can’t ~ why the hell you care? Man without pride what ya got? - That's what got your ass outta here, dosin‘ it brung it on back. Them people ‘round you done too good a job protectin’ their meal ticket, know what I‘m sayin’? Livin’ “easy”, for some men who don’t give a damn, that’s good, that be okay, people like you, they gotta pull themselves wide open an’ see what's livin’ inside.

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: That ain’t never happenin’ - There’s no one out there.  i2.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Maybe not, but if that damn time do come, ya find somethin’ standin’ in front of you, somethin’ that ain’t runnin’, ain‘’t backin' up, hittin’ on you when you’re too damn tired to breathe, you find that situation comin’ on ya, that's good, ‘cause that’s the only time people gonna know what they really made of is when they gettin’ hurt, when they scared - They get through it, then they gonna get the only kinda respect that matters in this damn world, self respect. They embrace and MASON leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The well-worn NEIGHBORHOOD CHURCH where ROCKY was married to ADRIAN. ROCKY’S car sits ACROSS THE STREET from the structure. INT. - ROCKY’S VAN — NIGHT ROCKY STARES at the building. PAULIE stares straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Whatta day. (after a pause) I was more nervous that day than any day that I ever had. This is torturous for PAULIE.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: What’s next?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROCKY is parked in front of the DEFUNCT PET SHOP. PAULIE sits in THE CAR.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Place ain’t changed from last year.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: What is that? A good thing?  12. ROCKY looks through the filthy and boarded-up windows. He steps back. He eyes the familiar structure with an AIR OF SENTIMENTALITY. FLASHBACK: Through ROCKY‘S eyes we see him flirting with ADRIAN who stands shyly behind a bird cage.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Everyday I used to try to find her somethin’ interestin’ like a joke I heard somewhere - They weren’t so funny, but I talk louder, so they sounded funny.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: -.-We done? Lost in thought - ROCKY looks ACROSS THE STREET. He gazes at the terribly weathered sign above "Mickey's Gym.”

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (softly) +--How ya doin’, Mick? THE DOOR AND THE WINDOWS are sealed up with sheets of PAINTED ALUMINUM.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That sign’s fallin’ apart.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: World’s fallin’ apart ~ Look at us —

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (taps his temple) C'mon - Don’t talk crazy ~ ya know, ya live some place long enough, you are that place.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: T ain’t no chunky buildin’ ~ C’mon, it’s gettin’ late.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: +-.One more stop. Exasperated, PAULIE sighs heavily and follows his friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera settles on ROCKY and PAULIE standing in front of a leveled pile of rubble nearly half a block long.  i3.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: Ice is stupid. People standin’ on ice are more stupid.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: +--C’mon

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: (almost to himself) I’m glad they tore this place down.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (stepping on to the rubble) Y'know, the first time I walked ya sister over this ice, we was over here (points) - She was nervous - I weren't so great on the blades neither. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: ROCKY and ADRIAN are seen skating on their first date - ADRIAN slips and ROCKY keeps her upright.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (points) Over there, when she was fallin’ I caught her over there - When my hand grabbed her arm when she was fallin’ there was this kinda buzz ~ Even through her coat I felt that.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: ++-Ya said that last year. Phone rings ~ PAULIE answers. He self-consciously turns away from ROCKY. PAULIE (CONT’D) Yeah - Fine -~ IT was gonna call ya in an hour - Yeah, call ya back. (hangs up) My sweetie gave me a phone ~ nice?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (still lost in thought) ».-Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: C’mon, Rocko.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: In a minute.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: Why another minute?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Just a minute, alright?

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: We’re done - (gestures) There’s no place to sit down around here.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: It’s all right.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: (louder) It‘s not all right! - It’s depressin’ an’ friggin’ cold!

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: What’s the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: Me? It’s you! Ya backwards! Change the channel from yesterday! Yesterday wasn't so great!

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: To me it was.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, maybe not to me! I don’t need to be thinkin’ about all this no more.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: It’s alright, Paulie.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: No, it ain’t alright! You treated her good! You had the good times. I treated her bad! Ya can’t change this!

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: -+-She loved you.  15.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: (choked) I can’t do this no more. PAULIE moves off in the OPPOSITE direction — ROCKY watches him shrink in the distance ~ ROCKY lowers his eyes and stares wistfully over the rubble. EXT. - ROCKY’S HOUSE ~ PRE-DAWN - BACK YARD (SCORED -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garbed in an old sweat suit, ROCKY is seen exercising in a MAKESHIFT MAZE of pipes and poles that resemble a giant JUNGLE GYM. His tiny backyard is quite a contrast to the mundane yards that surround him. INT. - PAULIE’S ROOM — MORNING Exiting the kitchen, he passes PAULIE’S room. PAULIE is asleep with A DARK SCARF tied around his eyes. The television is still on. ROCKY quietly enters and turns it off. A bottle of Four Roses whiskey sits on the table.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. - ROCKY’S KITCHEN — MORNING ROCKY finishes cooking OATMEAL for PAULIE which he covers and places on the table next to a GLASS OF ORANGE JUICE. As an afterthought he punches idly in the air. He opens the refrigerator and removes a pair of eggs that he cracks into a coffee cup. He tries unsuccessfully to down them. He pours the remainder down the sink and exits.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. - PRODUCE MARKET — EARLY MORNING The same MARKET that was once part of ROCKY’S glory days has changed. Drastically. The ITALIANS have been replaced with nearly all ASIANS. ROCKY stands with his READING GLASSES on, placing an order with A VIETNAMESE VENDOR who deals in cheeses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROCKY has placed an order with a Korean vendor and is presently loading his van with several crates of lettuce, celery and eggplant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROCKY is seen loading several crates of ice-packed fish into his van.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. — FRUIT SECTION ROCKY stands with one of the last remaining Italian vendors, who is somewhere between 75 and 150 years old. The stooped old man tosses ROCKY an orange and it falls short. The old man’s embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (in Italian) Ya throwin’ in to a wind.

dialogues.speaker: OLD ITALIAN
dialogues.text: (in Italian) +.-must be. The old man smiles as ROCKY moves away. EXT. — TOMILSON CORP. - MORNING We gaze upon the modern exterior of a towering building jutting out against the Philadelphia skyline.

dialogues.speaker: INT.
dialogues.text: We are in the lobby as we see an upscale young EXECUTIVES and SECRETARIES entering through the large doors preparing to begin another workday. ROCKY stands off to the side politely signing autographs for a heavyset Black woman and a middle aged white man. Through the glass facade, ROBERT JR. is seen entering the building. He is the complete contrast to his father. Slightly smaller than his father, his body language does not convey a sense of confidence.  17. His clothing is business attire, but simple, like someone who accepts just blending in. His face is attractive, not stunning. He is somewhat low in spirits, but tries to constantly mask it... ROBERT JR is confronted by a senior executive (30's) who appears to be verbally berating him. ROBERT JR’s gestures make it evident he is attempting to protest, but is bested by the executive, who points an angry finger in the young man’s face and exits. ROCKY has taken all this in.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Yo, Robert ~ At first, ROBERT JR. appears embarrassed then composes himself. ROCKY approaches. ROBERT JR. You've kinda caught me off guard.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: I wanted to catch you before you got busy ROBERT JR. Yeah - Gets busy up there.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: All that stuff goin’ on up there - I'd get a headache. How ya doin’? (studying him) ROBERT JR. -+--Real Good.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: ...Yeah? ROBERT JR. Yeah, real good.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Hopin’ to see ya yesterday. ROBERT JR. (sincerely) I’m sorry about yesterday ~ I went in early this morning. We had an issue come up. Mid-cap merger, they kept us late. People wave as they walk by. ROCKY politely ACKNOWLEDGES. This is not lost on ROBERT JR  18.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Got time for a coffee or somethin’? ROBERT JR. I'm kinda behind. Maybe later.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (ili at ease) Yeah, wanna come by the restaurant tonight. ROBERT UR. I would, but I’ve made some plans - A few of the guys get together - ¥’know

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Yeah, friends are good - (sheepishly) ++-Did I do something? ROBERT JR. What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: When I come around you don’t look so comfortable. Several people pass by and wave to the local celebrity as they head to the elevators. ROCKY returns the gesture. ROBERT JR. Y¥’know, you throw a big shadow.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: What’s that mean? ROBERT JR. It’s nothing - I better get moving. Call ya later? MR. TOMILSON (60s) The head C.E.0. and FOUNDER appears, heading towards ROCKY and his son. ROBERT GETS RED-FACED.

dialogues.speaker: TOMILSON
dialogues.text: (teasingly) You‘ll get nothing done down here, Robert - If you won’t introduce me, I will - (extends his hand) Hi I'm William Tomilson. Your son has the misfortune of working for me.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: How ya doin’? Nice building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ig. ROBERT JR. He’s kidding it’s a great job.

dialogues.speaker: TOMILSON
dialogues.text: I’ve told your Robert I’ve wanted to meet you 20 times but I guess you’ve been too busy, which isn’t a bad thing, is it? So we finally we meet - Great memories. Good fights.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: TOMILSON
dialogues.text: Your son‘s doing a pretty good job. Hangin’ in there ~ Nice finally meeting you face to face. They shake hands and TOMILSON moves off.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Good grip - ROBERT JR. (ill at ease) I better take off - I'll try to change some things and we can have dinner tonight - That all right?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Absolutely - See ya tonight. ROBERT JR. smiles and starts to move off in the direction of his boss. ROCKY’S about to leave when we see from ROBERT'S P.0.V. A pair of young business executives ask ROCKY for a photo. One of the men take ROCKY’S fist and holds it under his chin as the picture is taken, cur To:

dialogues.speaker: INT RESTAURANT
dialogues.text: Outside the MODEST RESTAURANT a light rain begins to fall. The door opens up and a pair of customers exit.  20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROCKY is seen in the distance telling a table of four tourists a ‘story’. The pregnant hostess comes up to him as he completes the story.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: ++-Your son said he can’t make it. Said he’ll take a ‘rain check’ ROCKY is crestfallen

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: -+-Yeah, it is rainin’, right?. (he moves off). EXT. ROCKY’S RESTAURANT. NIGHT. It is drizzling. The small neon sign “ROCKY’S” goes out. cur TO: EXT. ROCKY’S RESTAURANT. NIGHT. (ALLEY) ROCKY exits and locks up. He crosses to the van and pauses as his hand grabs the handle. He’s lost in thought. cUuT TO: EXT. - RADIO STATION —~ NIGHT MASON DIXON is situated in the guest’s chair. The BLACK RADIO TALK show host is BESPECTACLED and URBANE. L.Cc., MASON'S manager closely observes. Four homeboys pace and hang out in view of the host. Host Most people think you have the perfect life, fame, wealth, health and obviously your pick of female companionship. Do you have the perfect life?

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: »»-Some ways ‘yes,‘ some ways ‘no.’

dialogues.speaker: HOST
dialogues.text: What do you need to make it ‘perfect?’

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: Not sure that could ever be.

dialogues.speaker: HOST
dialogues.text: (nervous) Since you’re at the top of your game things must be looking ‘up’ right now.

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: From where I’m sittin’, guess that’s what it looks like. Off to the side we see L.C., MASON’S manager, stiffen.

dialogues.speaker: HOST
dialogues.text: You've been criticized about not living up to your potential, takin’ the road less travelled - Easy fights. Your comment?

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: +..Only that its true. The host shifts uncomfortably under MASON’S gaze.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. — LUCKY’S BAR - NIGHT The streets SHINE with a dampness and indifference. ROCKY is parked near the entrance of the familiar bar. He exits the vehicle. See’s a person (50s) exiting.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Andy still here? INT. ~ LUCKY’S BAR - NIGHT The CHEAPLY ANTIQUATED BARROOM is sparsely inhabited with no more than 12 world-weary patrons. ROCKY is shaking hands with a pair of GRIZZLED blue-collar workers in their early fifties. As he TRAVERSES THE ROOM MOST of the inhabitants now are AWARE of the neighborhood hero's arrival and shake his hand. A booth of the four LATE-TWENTIES STREET TRASH drinkers eye ROCKY and exchange demeaning expressions. ROCKY approaches at the bar and sees ANDY seated in a wheelchair. He is missing a leg.  22.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Yo, Andy -

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Thought I was seein’ things - Maybe I am seein’ things ~ How ya doin’ champ? what‘’re you, lost or somethin’?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Can‘t I miss ya? -

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Never thought I’d see you around here -

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Yeah...What happened?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Lost it to diabetes - I roll around ‘alright - Slide over here. ANDY wheels himself to the far edge of the bar and appears from around the corner. ANDY (CONT’D) T usually stay back there, ‘cause I don't want nobody feelin’ bad for me or crap like that.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: I feel bad for ya.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Hey, it’s one way of losin’ weight, right? (uncomfortable, Rocky shrugs} Nothin’ changed around here, same everythin’. The STREET TRASH now gesture towards ROCKY. A stoned 20s woman rises from the booth. ANDY (CONT’D) Same comfortable junk. Listen, read about ya wife’s passin’ a while back.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: +»-Yeah, ‘woman’s cancer.’

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Nice girl -  23.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: «.Best.

dialogues.speaker: HIGH WOMAN
dialogues.text: (taps Rocky’s shoulder) ++-That really him? That's you, right?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Sweetheart we’re havin’ a drink here -—

dialogues.speaker: HIGH WOMAN
dialogues.text: (hugs him) - C'mon - My father said you were pretty good. Ya from here, right? She awkwardly squeezes his arm. The woman makes A COMICAL FACE towards her friend. ROCKY CATCHES THIS. HIGH WOMAN (CONT’D) (squeezing) Pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable) Nice meetin’ ya.

dialogues.speaker: HIGH WOMAN
dialogues.text: Why ya back here?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Hey, we're talkin’

dialogues.speaker: HIGH WOMAN
dialogues.text: (overriding) Sorry, listen, could ya buy me an’ my friends a round, okay? We're over there, One round. The women gestures towards the booth of LOW LIFES and squeezes ROCKY’s arm again. He removes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: HIGH WOMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why ya doin’ that? - Why ya pushin’ my hand?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Young lush, take it over there or get out.

dialogues.speaker: HIGH WOMAN
dialogues.text: {to Rocky) Yeah... Hey, you’re just a person too — No better - (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: HIGH WOMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: {backs up) No better She coldly eyes him, returns to the booth.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: One second they like ya, next second you're a bum. Guess that’s gravity workin’.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Ain’t ya glad ya dropped in?. From out of the BACK ROOM A WOMAN APPEARS. She is heavyset and not overly attractive. Her hair has seen one TOO MANY PERMS. There’s a SAD SWEETNESS about her, like someone who’s made too many wrong choices, and has to live with them. She approaches.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Tf ya don‘t need me anymore, Andy, I’m takin’ off.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: I got it from here - See ya tomorrow, Marie. ROCKY studies her face, trying to place it.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: She local?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Yeah - Local. Marie’s her name.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Do I know her?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Talkin’ to me or yourself?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: +.-Me - I hate forgettin’ things.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: My brain’s mush too. (Andy waves her over) - Marie MARIE removes a coat from a wall hock and approaches.  25.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know this bum?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: How ya doin’?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. You sorta knew my brother, Joey. (no response) Ya walked me home once - Long time ago Hundred years.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Wait - Wait - Are you Lil’ Marie from the Atomic Hoagie Shop? From behind the bar, ANDY starts rolling forward.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Yeah ~ Ya told'me‘to stop smokin’.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Did I?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: (nods) Yeah, long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, an’ after I was tellin’ ya good things, ya said “Screw you creepo.”

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: You remember that?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Good insults last a long time.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: If she knew you were gonna be famous she woulda listened better.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: (distracted) Probably, yeah, listen, I gotta go - Really good seein’ ya. MARIE starts towards the exit.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Live far from here?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: About eight blocks from here.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: It’s still kinda a rough neighborhood. Let me give ya a lift.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: (low) Y‘know, I still smoke

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: +..Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: No...dust kiddin’. - LUCKY’S BAR - NIGHT ROCKY approaches his van with MARIE.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Ya workin’ here long?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: (shyly ‘Bout a year.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: .».Where was ya residin’ before?

dialogues.speaker: MARTE
dialogues.text: Atlantic City.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Nice ~- You married?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Sorta.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Sorta.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: He took off.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Poof - Just like that?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Just like that.  276

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Sorta have any kids?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: +..One,

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Me too. The STREET TRASH GROUP comes out of the bar. Three of the group are men. One drops a BEER BOTTLE and they loudly joke about it. The leader of the group is not OVERLY TALL, BUT THICK, menacing.

dialogues.speaker: LEADER
dialogues.text: (spotting Rocky) Yo, why didn’t ya buy us a drink. She was being nice to your ass. What's up with that?

dialogues.speaker: HIGH WOMAN
dialogues.text: He wants to talk to that ugly bitch. You blind?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (to Marie) You should get in. Embarrassed, MARIE lowers herself into the van.

dialogues.speaker: LEADER
dialogues.text: Yeah, go on, get in, Get that pig outta here! ROCKY enters the van. The group laughs among themselves... ROCKY places the key in the ignition. Out of the corner of his eye, he sees MARIE tearing up.

dialogues.speaker: ROCRY
dialogues.text: You alright?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: .--Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Some people got big mouths - MARIE remains silent.  28.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Words don’t mean nothin’ unless they're true - Right? MARIE nods. ROCKY (CONT’D) People called me stuff my whole life - I ignore it. HIS GUTS TIGHTEN. ROCKY turns the engine off.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Don’t get out - It’s alright.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY -'
dialogues.text: No, Lil’ Marie - It ain’t alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In one energized moment, ROCKY gets out, AND CHARGES at the leader with unexpected FORCE.

dialogues.speaker: LEADER
dialogues.text: Yo, what's up!? What’s up! The leader is slammed with a forearm to the chest and pinned against a parked car. A SECOND MAN attempts to intercede and is leveled with an elbow. THE REST BACK OFF. We see the alteration from MARIE'S P.0O.V. ROCKY walks back to the van and enters. MARIE is stunned,

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: ---They apologized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROBERT JR. exits and waves good-bye to several office buddies while speed dialing his cell phone. cur TO:  29. INT. ~ ROCKY’S RESTAURANT - NIGHT A ringing phone is heard in the darkened restaurant. curt TO: EXT. -— STREET - NIGHT ROBERT JR. flips is cell phone shut and ambles away. EXT. - MARIE’S ROW HOUSE - NIGHT Still in FISHTOWN, ROCKY’S van pulls towards the curb in front of an old Row House. Across the street is a medium sized 16 YEAR OLD WHITE KID of Irish decent and a taller HALF-BLACK KID. They are playing street BASKETBALL under a SAGGING HOOP attached to a LAMPPOST.

dialogues.speaker: INT.
dialogues.text: ROCKY pulls to the curb.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Thanks for the ride - Sorry ‘bout everythin’ back there.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Hey, some people got their heads on backwards. (points) That ya kid? She looks across the narrow street at the young men playing ball.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: -+-Yeah ~ Wish he wouldn‘t stay out so late.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: The last I seen ya, ya were a kid, it’s hard to believe ya officially got one of ya own.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Good kid.  30. ROCKY observes her sandy-haired son through the WINDSHIELD.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: He looks like you. Similar hair.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: It’s the other one.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (awkward) ~.-Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (at a loss) ++-Looks like he’s gonna be tall.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: His father was from Jamaica.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: ...Yeah

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Good beaches. ROCKY (CONT’D) {eyes the kid) - Is he lookin’ like he’s mad at me or is it maybe the angle I’m sittin’ at?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: No, he’s a good kid.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: What’s his name?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: ‘Steps’ - Short for Stevenson. Wanna meet him?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable) It’s kinda late - Got some things to do.  31.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Sure ~ Thanks again for the ride an’ everythin’ else.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Yeah - ROCKY puts the van in GEAR, then PAUSES.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: ++.Yo. ROCKY gets out of the VAN and steps to the curb. ROCKY (CONT’D) I didn’t meet ya kid. How ya doin’? MARIE pauses for a second to study ROCKY. STEPS. fo (low) +.-What’s up?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Know who this is? STEPS shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: I look unfamiliar - Don’t worry about it. Listen, Lil’ Marie, (he fumbles around his jacket and gives her a card) I got this little place, y’know, restaurant - Maybe if ya in the neighborhood...wWho knows?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Sure - thanks again. ROCKY settles back in his van and drives off. EXT. - ROCKY’S HOUSE - NIGHT ROCKY’s car TURNS THE CORNER and approaches his residence. Through the windshield he catches a glimpse of PAULIE’S 50-ish girlfriend, BETTY, exiting his front door with SEVERAL CARDBOARD BOXES. She awkwardly places the BOX OF CLOTHES near the car.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: How ya doin’?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Good - How ya doin’, Betty?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Good - Paulie gave me the key an’ asked me to come over an’ get his stuff.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: -. Why?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: He wants to move in with me. He didn’t tell ya?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: {at a loss) Yeah, he said that. ROCKY lifts a box and places it in her trunk.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: You‘’re not mad?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (brave front) No - I was waitin’ to getta dog - Y¥’know some people can’t handle fur.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Good - So I think I’ve got everythin’ - If not, I’1l be back in the morning - Nice seein’ you again. ROCKY nods and she departs. He is crestfallen.- EXT. — SHAMROCK MEAT PACKING COMPANY - NIGHT Rocky’s van is PARKED NEXT TO A LOADING BAY.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: Can I be honest with ya?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: Ya know ya can - We cut into the INTERIOR OF THE SLAUGHTER HOUSE. ROCKY and PAULIE walk along an endless row of MEAT HOOKS that line the ceiling like GRUESOME CHANDELIERS... RAVI is seen sweeping in the backyard.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: Your house is nice -—

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: - It ain’t just my house, it‘s your’s too.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: I din’t pay nuthin’ - Lately the house has gotten uncomfortable, Rocko.

dialogues.speaker: ROCRY
dialogues.text: How's that?

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: Lately it’s not a ‘happy’ place - Lately the place is dark.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Dark?

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: Dark.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Whatta ya mean ‘dark?’ Like personality ‘dark,’ ‘paint’ dark; what?

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: (soft) It ain’t about the ‘paint,’ Rocko. {to Ravi) We need privacy here! Can ya hear that? (Ravi takes off)

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Yo, why ya breakin’ this guys chops?

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: He’s used to it - Y’know, I haven't had a ‘close’ woman, ever. So I’m takin’ the advantage. What, I’m not allowed to have a relationship before I’m dead? Anybody try to stop you?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Ya happy Paulie?

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: (gestures at the beef) Happiness comes in different cuts.  34. PAULIE (CONT’D) Choice, flank, rump...Yo, we'll visit a lot.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Yeah, give me a call.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: .--What’s the number again?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: It’s the same number for years.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: Hey, I don’t call myself. ROCKY takes a pen out of PAULIE’S top pocket.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Got some paper? PAULIE extends his hand and turns it over.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: Top side’s dryer. (Rocky writes) Y'know, I’m there for ya - We're always like brothers. PAULIE pats ROCKY’S shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: {moves off) -.-Appreciate it.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: Dinners at my place for a change - No charge. The ex-fighter weakly smiles and disappears from view. EXT. - ROCKY’S RESTAURANT ~ NIGHT The RAIN beats ceaselessly on the PAVEMENT in front of the establishment. INT. - ROCKY’S RESTAURANT - NIGHT In the subdued light we see only SIX CUSTOMERS. Two are boxers. One is SPIDER RICO, one of ROCKY’S old opponents. The kitchen employees stand nearly motionless.  35. TWO WAITERS make small talk near the bar. FOUR CUSTOMERS sit with ROCKY who is telling a well-worn story in his well-worn blazer. One of the listeners is a dark haired boy of 18 who sits beside his heavyset father.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: I don’t think I won a point for five rounds - He punched the you-know-what outta me - I’m grabin’, duckin’, blockin’, but he kept comin’ - Everything he throwed landed some place in the face area. He was hammerin’ me up pretty good every time. An’ when I nailed him, he nailed me. But truthfully you couldn’t miss me, you could throw a punch under both ya legs an’ around ya back an’ hit me square between the lamps (points to his eyes) So me goin’ the distance was a miracle of sorts. Yeah, Creed’s gotta go down in my book as one of the all-time greats. (rises)

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Picture with the kid, Rock? That alright? ROCKY smiles at the young man who somewhat resembles his son. ROCKY grabs his fist and places it under his chin.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: ++.Makes ya look more hazardous. They both smile and ROCKY rises. ISABEL comes over and gestures towards kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: HOSTESS
dialogues.text: Spider’s in the kitchen. ROCKY walks over to him. He’s washing dishes.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Yo, Spider —

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER
dialogues.text: Lemme do some dishes - I‘1l feel better.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: {takes the dish rag) C’mon, you’re my guest.

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER
dialogues.text: Then let me do somethin’.  36. ‘ ROCKY Keep chewin‘, do that. He leads SPIDER out. The piped-in MUSIC is drowned out by the sound of cascading rain. MARIE AND HER SON ENTER. MARIE RETRACTS A SMALL UMBRELLA. ROCKY appears completely caught off guard by the new arrivals. ROCKY (CONT’D) Hey - Ya kept the card.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Yeah - I kept the card -

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Good, how ya doin’, Steps? viene STEPS ».-Alright.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Picked a bad night to show up, Lil’ Marie.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: It’s my only night off - (eyes the mural) Nice paintin’ - Nice place. Nice isn’t it? STEPS sullenly nods - ROCKY smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: It’s toco ol’ fashioned for him - Here, sit wherever ya want - Hungry?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: A little - You cook?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (shrugs) No, I don’t mess with the pans. Whatta ya feel like eatin’, Steps?

dialogues.speaker: STEPS
dialogues.text: Got what I need, STEPS reaches into his jacket and pulls out bottled water ¢ : and a McDONALD’S BURGER.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Sorry...

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: +..Tough competition.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. - MASON’S VEGAS HOUSE - NIGHT On a lit COURT we see the solitary figure of MASON DIXON shooting a basketball alone - In the background, his well lit home is seen and MUSIC is heard emanating from within. INT. - E.S.P.N. SET -— NIGHT Two regular commentators are flanked by THREE WRITERS. Behind them is a large curved screen. The overhead lights beat down on the congregation.

dialogues.speaker: COMMENTATOR
dialogues.text: Welcome once again to “E.S.P.N.‘s Man vs. Machine.” Who was really the ‘best?’ If two athletes from two different eras were to actually compete against one another? Given the same rules, placed together at the same age, using the same equipment, who would truly triumph? INT. - MASON’S MODERN HOME (VEGAS) - NIGHT Five of DIXON’S POSSE are listening to Hip Hop while shooting pool. The room is full of many arcade video games. Behind the men is a large plasma television that one of the posse is channel-surfing through. He stops at an E.S.P.N. show. MASON DIXON'S still image is on the screen.

dialogues.speaker: POSSE MEMBER
dialogues.text: +--Check it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROBERT JR, sits with a group of three friends. These guys are not “players” or ‘studs’, just average white collar men. Most of the bar’s TVs are showing ASSORTED BALL GAMES.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: «+-Look at this. The group's attention is dawn to the E.S.P.N. broadcast. They see a picture of ROCKY and MASON DIXON on the screen. ROBERT IS CAUGHT OFF GUARD.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: (to bartender) Could you turn that up, please.

dialogues.speaker: COMMENTATOR
dialogues.text: This week we will feed our facts into “the machine” while fielding the comments of our illustrious panel of sports writers about who they think would reign supreme.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. — MASON DIXON HOME - NIGHT MASON’S manager, L.C., steps out into the patio and gestures to DIXON who’s still shooting baskets. L.c. Yo, man — curT TO: INT. — MASON’S HOME - NIGHT All present are viewing E.S.P.N. on the LARGE PLASMA SCREEN. We see an old film version of Rocky Marciano, well past his prime, and a young Muhammad Ali boxing in a dark make-shift ring.

dialogues.speaker: COMMENTATOR
dialogues.text: Originally conceived in 1969, then suspended, Ali was asked to box against the long-retired “Brockton Block Buster” Marciano. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: COMMENTATOR
dialogues.text: After all the data was fed into the computer a decision would be reached — Well, folks, following along those lines, and with the added plus of vastly improved technology, we will attempt to follow along the same lines... On the screen are MANY COMPUTER GENERATED RECREATIONS OF FORMER GREAT ATHLETES. COMMENTATOR #1 (CONT’D) This evening, Boxing once again - two contrasting styles in every conceivable way. The champion and undisputed holder of the heavyweight crown for nearly three and a half years.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. — BASKETBALL COURT - NIGHT MASON and L.C. view the show on a flat screen located in a LOUNGE AREA. The house is seen in the background. The computer-generated and shockingly life-like images of ROCKY and MASON flash across the screen.

dialogues.speaker: COMMENTATOR
dialogues.text: The controversial Mason "The Line” Dixon will be pitted against the straight-ahead style of southpaw Philly slugger, Rocky Balboa. Now let’s go to our virtual arena and the opening bell!! As the bell rings, the screen SWITCHES TO A SIMULATED BOXING RING. The VISUAL OF MASON “THE LINE” DIXON and a much YOUNGER ROCKY charge across the ring! MASON CRASHES A HUGE RIGHT AGAINST ROCKY’S JAW... EXT. — MARIA‘S HOUSE - NIGHT ROCKY‘s car swings to the curb, MARIE exits with her arms dladen with food-to-go. STEPS exits also cradling boxes o food. He prepares to enter the house.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Thanks again.  40.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Sure - Listen, think Steps wants a job? Make a few extra bucks weekends ~ It’s good makin’ ya own money - My kid stashed a few bucks. MARIE leans closer to the car.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Why’re you being so nice?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: ¥’know, I - ah - don’t want ya to think nothin’s off, y ‘know? My wife -— She's gone, but she isn’t, know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: I wasn’t thinkin’ that.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: What were ya thinkin’?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: - That you don’t owe us nothin’

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Why d’you gotta be owin’ somethin’ to get somethin’? ...Spendin’ time with ya kid would be nice. Whatta ya think?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: That‘d be good.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: -».Appreciate it.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. — MASON’S HOUSE - NIGHT DIXON, looking melancholy, watches the computer fight wrapping up. It is the LAST ROUND. The PIXILATED version of ROCKY BALBOA attacking his counterpart. The BATTLE CONTINUES for another fifteen seconds. The BELL rings. BOTH GRAPHIC IMAGES FREEZE. FULL-SCREEN: Beneath frozen images of the fighter are instant COMPUTER GRAPHICS of the BALBOA/MASON DIXON COMPUTER BATTLE, such a POWER PUNCHES THROWN, JABS, KNOCK DOWNS, ETC.

dialogues.speaker: COMMENTATOR
dialogues.text: Well, gentlemen that was a lot of give and take - Now let’s hear it from our ‘live’ experts. Bernie Hernandez, Philadelphia Daily News.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Given the power punches landed and the fact Dixon’s never been in deep, never faced real adversity - Balboa wins!

dialogues.speaker: INT.
dialogues.text: ROBERT and his group sit transfixed. ROBERT is very ill at ease.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: Your ol’ man’s the man!

dialogues.speaker: COMMENTATOR
dialogues.text: What say you, Michael Katz - Reuters?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Balboa’s had the much harder competition. Dixon’s got fantastic skills! Super fast! But fed easy opponents by his management team, so I call it Balboa hands down! ROBERT’S friends applaud.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: (good natured) What happened to you? ROBERT JR tries to look amused but is sick at heart. cur TO: EXT. - MASON’S HOUSE ~ LOUNGE AREA ~ NIGHT DIXON is deeply wounded by the lack of respect. His eyes are pained.

dialogues.speaker: COMMENTATOR
dialogues.text: Now what say you, Burt Sugar, of Ring Magazine?  42.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I agree Dixon fights pushovers, so who knows what he’s made of? - But each in their prime, factoring Dixon’s unbelievable speed and slashing offense, he cuts Balboa to bits. Dixon all the way.

dialogues.speaker: COMMENTATOR
dialogues.text: Well, let’s see what the computer has to say. So let's have it. A PICTURE OF ROCKY BALBOA IN HIS FIGHTING PRIME bursts on one half of the screen with statistics on the other.

dialogues.speaker: COMMENTATOR
dialogues.text: Taking the human factor out of it, the computer says, the “Philly Slugger,” Rocky Balboa would be triumphant over reigning champion Mason Dixon in a 15 round decision - There you have it folks! DIXON shakes his head in dismay.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: You believe that? L.c. Hell with what strangers think. Who's got the money? (points to the house) Those are your people, they love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROBERT’S group applaud and comically point to ROBERT. It is all done in good fun, but ROBERT is very uncomfortable with the attention. One friend holds up his fist.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: I'm never messing with you!

dialogues.speaker: COMMENTATOR
dialogues.text: +»-Well that’s it for this evening - Next week’s challenge, basketball - we will pit Wilt ‘The Stilt’ Chamberlain against ‘The Big Diesel’ Shaquille O’Neal ~ Hope to see you then. cur TO:  43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seated on his portable folding chair, ROCKY sits in front of his wife’s grave.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: {to headstone) Y'know, the thing is, I know ya gone, I go and I visit ya grave but I still expect ya to be waitin’ at home - I never knew I could have these kinda thoughts ~ I think it’s some kind of crazy joke like God is playin’ an’ I’m gonna go home an’ the lights'll come on an’ I’ll hear these people yellin’ “Surprise” an’ out steps you. That’s never gonna happen but I keep thinkin’ it will... I try talkin’ to the kid; we're I think, goin’ in different directions. -~. ‘” Y'know I ain’t done nothin’ right since you left... EXT. — PRODUCE MARKET ~ DAY ROCKY and STEPS load stacked crates of produce into ROCRY’S van. Both are damp with sweat.

dialogues.speaker: STEPS
dialogues.text: Why ain’t somebody else doin’ the loadin’ - You paid for it, why we doin’ it?”

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Makes ya head stronger.

dialogues.speaker: STEPS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Makes ya head stronger - Sometimes I used to stare at this far away street light for nearly half an hour without blinkin’ — Or I‘d be squeezin’ a ball until my hands felt like they was gonna explode - (lifts several more crates)

dialogues.speaker: STEPS
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: I was trainin’ myself to do things that were uncomfortable, because I knew gettin’ used to being uncomfortable might come in handy some day - Like when some sledgemhammer pug is tryin’ to flatten parts of ya head an’ body.

dialogues.speaker: STEPS
dialogues.text: So, why you tellin’ me this?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Jus‘ makin’ conversation.

dialogues.speaker: STEPS
dialogues.text: Don’t need to.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Then who should I be talkin’ to, seagulls? (looks up) I’m talkin’ to ya ‘cause I think ya a nice kid an’ ya got a nice mother.

dialogues.speaker: STEPS
dialogues.text: Why you call her Lil’ Marie?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: ‘Cause that's how I know her.

dialogues.speaker: STEPS
dialogues.text: She ain’t Lil’.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Whatta ya want me to call her, “Huge?”

dialogues.speaker: STEPS
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Yo - Don’t be goofin’ on ya mother.

dialogues.speaker: STEPS
dialogues.text: She‘s my mother.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: You argue pretty good, don’t ya? - Hey, ya ever hear from ya father?

dialogues.speaker: STEPS
dialogues.text: Why?  45.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Curious. Him being gone bother ya?

dialogues.speaker: STEPS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Sure it does.

dialogues.speaker: STEPS
dialogues.text: ---No it doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: My ‘ol man took it on the arches, an’ it bothered me. Mother took off too ~ In a different direction.

dialogues.speaker: STEPS
dialogues.text: What ya do?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Tt botheres me a lot. Still does ~ But whatta ya gonna do? - Cry every day? Ya take ya lumps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPS actually seems taken by the man’s candor.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ya very lucky. Ya gotta a mother who loves ya and ain’t quittin’ ya. So listen to what she says, ‘cause if ya listen to what them dumb bell idiots on the street say - You'll end up doin’ a lotta wrong, like me.

dialogues.speaker: STEPS
dialogues.text: What’re you sayin’. Man, you went all the way.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: It was freak luck.

dialogues.speaker: STEPS
dialogues.text: Then gimme freak luck.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Freak luck’s for suckers.

dialogues.speaker: . STEPS
dialogues.text: 4 Worked for you.  46.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Hey - Forget me! - Waitin’ for freak luck is for dunces, ya gotta go get what ya want an’ if ya get knocked down, so what, ya got legs, ya get up an’ if ya don't get up, so what. It’s alright ‘cause ya tried. Who do you wanna be? The guy on the ground who tried somethin’ or the bum standin’ up who did nothin’? Personally I’d like to be the guy on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: STEPS
dialogues.text: Think you got it all together?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: I din‘t say that.

dialogues.speaker: STEPS
dialogues.text: Then why’re you wastin’ my time? ROCKY laughs and throws a mock punch at STEPS who smiles. He wipes the sweat away on his sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: ..-Wiseguy. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bland building stands alone. Barking can be heard over the exterior.

dialogues.speaker: INT.
dialogues.text: ROCKY and STEPS walk along a multitude of cages.

dialogues.speaker: STEPS
dialogues.text: (points at a Pit Bull) That’s a good one.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: He don’t look friendly - How ‘bout him? He points to an ugly flat-headed mutt.

dialogues.speaker: STEPS
dialogues.text: Him?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Why not?  a7.

dialogues.speaker: STEPS
dialogues.text: He’s ugly.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (bends down) Yeah, but it’s a nice ugly. Yo - C’mere, Boy, come on.

dialogues.speaker: STEPS
dialogues.text: How ‘bout a young one. The dog looks barely alive.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: See, he ain’t wastin’ energy.

dialogues.speaker: STEPS
dialogues.text: ‘Cause he’s dead.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: There‘s mileage left on this animal - A little good food, bingo - watch out - Give ‘im a name?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Yo, what’s a good name?

dialogues.speaker: STEPS
dialogues.text: it’s your dog.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: No - It’s a community animal.

dialogues.speaker: STEPS
dialogues.text: I don’t know nothin’ ‘bout no dogs.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: c’mon - Think.

dialogues.speaker: STEPS
dialogues.text: Flea bag

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: That’s probably taken - Somethin’ else

dialogues.speaker: STEPS
dialogues.text: (stares at Rocky) Punchy.  48. ROCKY dryly eyes STEPS. STEPS does not know if he’s crossed the line.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: “Punchy.”

dialogues.speaker: STEPS
dialogues.text: (repentant) I was just playin’

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Were ya?

dialogues.speaker: STEPS
dialogues.text: ++-yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: +++T like it. ROCKY eyes the mangy animal and: laughs.

dialogues.speaker: STEPS
dialogues.text: For real?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Yeah - Very classy, different. Yo, Punchy - Time to hit the road. INT. ~ ROCKY’S RESTAURANT - NIGHT We see STEPS near the stove. ‘Punchy’ sits in the corner. Rocky is feeding him pieces of cheese as he slips into his old sport blazer.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: That‘s good, kid - Keep the spoon movin’. STEPS continues to churn the risotto as instructed.

dialogues.speaker: DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: Half the room is occupied - PAULIE enters through the front door and heads to the kitchen. He is wearing his NIGHT WATCHMAN’S UNIFORM.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: Rocko!

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: PAULTIE
dialogues.text: They’re gonna be talkin’ about the fake ‘Loony Tune’ fight.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: What fight?

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: (points) The ‘Fake’ one on television. PAULIE crosses to the small bar and turns on the television. ROCKY gestures to the 14 people who are dining. Also present are two ex-fighters who are also eating.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: People are eatin’ -

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: (towards the ex-fighters) Helps ‘em digest - I come as a favor. The SCREEN BRIGHTENS and STEPS approaches the bat. PAULIE (CONT’D) (faces Rocky) Who's the criminal?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (gestures) He’s a nice kid.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: He dresses like a bum.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: What’re you, a work of art?

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: Hide the silverware. They all face the TELEVISION. Several customers drift over. An E.S.P.N. BROADCAST appears. On screen is AN ACTUAL 41220 EILM featuring the REAL ROCKY MARCTANO who is nearl 50 years old. He is about to engage in a SIMULATED FIGHT with MOHAMMED ALI who is 27 YEARS OLD.

dialogues.speaker: COMMENTATOR
dialogues.text: +.-In the late Sixties a simulated fight took place between two legends - Rocky Marciano and Mohammed Ali - Ali, unable to fight legitimately for three years for having refused induction into the Armed Forces, was in need of money and agreed to the so-called ‘Dream Match’ whose outcome would be decided by a computer. On screen we see ALI and MARCIANO battling. COMMENTATOR (CONT’D) ---It's almost thirty-five years since Rocky Marciano won the much-disputed computer decision. Well, guess what? Not much has changed! Now the MODERN FIGHT between a PIXILATED VERSION of Dixon and Balboa’ appears...The super realistic battle has ROCK TRANSFIXED... The two ex-pugs drift over. One is SPIDER RICO.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: The owner’s fightin’. CLOSE-UP: Television

dialogues.speaker: COMMENTATOR
dialogues.text: Last week, Rocky Balboa, won a decisive “computer decision” over present-day Champion Mason Dixon. More of the restaurant crowd comes over,

dialogues.speaker: COMMENTATOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ++-But what started out as a simple form of entertainment has become a lightning red for many who feel that the “old school” athlete like Balboa was better, while Dixon’s manager says, like the Ali- Marciano computer decision in 1970, which Marciano won, the Balboa decision, could be nothing more than thinly disguised racism -

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: (to screen) Get therapy. MASON DIXON COMES ON THE SCREEN.  51. e MASON It’s unfortunate man, but people’re in the habit of tryin’ to destroy other people. It’s the way the world is - Stick ya head above the crowd, people try to cut it off. Ain’t got nothin’ against the man, he’s being used, like I’m being used.

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER
dialogues.text: Ya woulda murdered him.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: This ain’t real, Spider. TV cuts back to pair of IRREVERENT ANCHORMEN.

dialogues.speaker: ANCHOR
dialogues.text: (comically) . So, how do you think Balboa-would’ve done against Dixon?

dialogues.speaker: ANCHOR
dialogues.text: Easy Win - Personally I think Balboa was Qverrated.

dialogues.speaker: ANCHOR
dialogues.text: You know that Rocky owns a little restaurant in South Philly. What do you think the speciality is?

dialogues.speaker: ANCHOR
dialogues.text: Pounded chicken.

dialogues.speaker: ANCHOR
dialogues.text: Very good! I was gonna say cauliflowered ears.

dialogues.speaker: ANCHOR
dialogues.text: {a pix of The Eagles comes on screen) Early today Eagles coach...

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: That's it? That was a waste of my time. Rocky reddens as everyone feels his discomfort. PAULIE turns the TV off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4 That was good advertisin”  52.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: Yeah ~ (takes a bottle of booze) Pay later. The meathouse calls (exits)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROCKY is parked across the street from the mid-income building. A doorman paces inside. Several moments later, ROBERT JR. approaches. ROCKY exits and approaches.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Yo, Robert ROBERT JR. (startled) What is this? What‘re you doin’ out so late?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: I tried callin’ - Nothin’ was pickin’ up. ROBERT JR. Somethin’ wrong?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: No ~ I just wanted to see ya in person. ROBERT JR. Wanna come inside?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Nah - Y'know ya mother had good opinions on things. I'm sure you do too. ROBERT JR. Sure...Opinion on what?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Y'know, the rumor is we only live once. ROBERT JR. Yeah, I’ve heard that.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: IT wanna do somethin’ -  ROBERT JR. - Like what ?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Fight. ROBERT JR. (thunderstruck) ---You’re serious

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Yeah - I thought maybe ya wanna get involved. ROBERT JR. Involved? How?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Y¥‘know- Help me, hang out for support. Ain't many of us left. ROBERT JR. People will think you’ve lost it.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: I don’t mind. ROBERT JR. You should mind -

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: ~ Why? They ain’t blood. ROBERT JR. Don’t you think you’re to - old?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Yeah, on the outside ~ But the insides work pretty good. ROBERT JR. takes a moment and shakes his head in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ~ Think ya should ever stop ‘trying things’ ‘cause ya had a few too many birthdays? I don’t. ROBERT JR. This isn’t about just ‘trying things.’ When you’re done you're done. You know that? 53.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Maybe ya stronger some place else. ROBERT JR. Please use some “common sense.”

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Let’s try. You an’ me. ROBERT JR. Why? It’s wrong. People will think your crazy.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: What’s crazy with standin’ toe to toe sayin’ “IAM.” ROBERT JR. That’s just ego talkin’. Time catches up to everybody.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Especially if you’re standin’ still. ROBERT JR. What are you tryin’ to prove to other people?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Nuthin’ - Except for ya mother, I stopped thinkin, what other people think a long time ago. Yo, think what you think. ROBERT JR. I do!

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Do ya? ROBERT JR. You‘ve got to face reality. It’s a different world now.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Only the clothes is different - Same world. ROBERT JR. What do you want from me? Really?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Nothin’ - I thought you might - forget it, it’s alright ROBERT JR. (touched) ---Whatever it is, whatever you’re goin’ through, it’ll pass - maybe too much time alone is not good. ROCKY awkwardly glances around. ROBERT hugs his father.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: «+I know ROBERT JR. Call you in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: ++-Sure. Disheartened, ROCKY moves off towards his van, a his son shakes his head in frustration and enters the apartment building. INT. —- MEATHOUSE - NIGHT ROCKY is walking along the HANGING BEEF, then exits the freezer with PAULIE. RAVI is seen in the background picking up odd bits of trash.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: Than ya brain’s tellin’ ya a bad joke - Nobody’s givin’ you no title shot.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: I know that.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: So there’s no mental disturbance?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: None I see.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: Ya miss people yellin’ ya name, don’t ya? One time around’s all we get.  56.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Maybe yeah, maybe no.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: Ya mad they took down ya statue?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: That don’t matter.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: Listen, if this is about money, hang a sign around ya neck that says “Punch me! Five Doliars! You’ll make big money (sips whiskey)

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: C’mon, Paulie. I got somethin, I wanna do. i+ PAULIE What? Ya ain’t ‘peaked’ yet?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: I dunno - There’s stuff in the basement.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: “Basement” ?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (touches his stomach) In here, there‘s stuff that’s gotta get out.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: What stuff?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Just stuff.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: My basement’s empty.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Maybe ya lucky - You with me?

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: I gotta job here.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Ya hate it.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: So? - I hate everythin’.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: You’re stayin’ here?

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: (sips from a flask) Yeah, among the beef. Tell your kid this?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: Thought you were nuts, Right? ROCKY turns away.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey. Nobody believes in ya — Welcome to my friggin’ life. ROCKY starts to exit Yo, I got some more things to say.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: ---That’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: PAULIE
dialogues.text: Its free

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: - That's okay He disappears around the corner. cuUT TO: EXT. — LUCKY’S BAR - NIGHT ROCKY is seen on the desolate streets with MARIE. The mangy dog, PUNCHY is with him.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Don’t you wanna come inside?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: The dog needs exercise. Ya kid did real good today.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: That’s good - So everything’s alright?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Listen, whatta ya think ‘bout comin’ over to the restaurant -

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: For work ~- The hostess is havin’ a kid. You’d do good.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know -

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Really, you'd do good. You'd do real good

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: I appreciate what you’re doin’ for my kid, But I can’t...I gotta get back.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Y'know, it’s a nicer neighborhood over there - Pleasant.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Can we drop it?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: What's botherin’ ya?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: It’s alright - I gotta get back

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: It’s not alright.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: C'mon -

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: I'm suppose to be the first person people see when they walk in?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Yeah, ya give ‘em menu’s, y'know. It’s not that complicated

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Look at me?  59.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: You could walk two blocks from here an‘ find ten better people - One block!

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: That’s wrong thinkin’.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: I just won’t feel comfortable ~ I can’t.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Give it a try - Two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: I don’t wanna try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yo who put this stuff in ya head?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Nobody -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C’mon, it don’t get in there itself. MARIE remains silent and starts to head back to the bar. ROCKY (CONT’D) Y'know, this way you're thinkin’ now, ya gotta forget all that!. So ya don’t think ya look good, so what, who’s perfect? — Maybe a couple of freaks of nature? But did ya ever really notice the mugs on the people that really do the great things, the important things? ~ It ain’t never the pretty ones, Lil’ Marie, It’s the real ones.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Really, I can’t -

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: An’ if you say “screw you creepo” again, I’m gonna whack myself so hard, I’m gonna go flyin’ over this bridge an’ you’1l be responsible! 4 : MARIE finally breaks a smile and hugs him.  60.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yo, get inside before ya catch somethin’. Marie re-enters the bar. ROCKY pats the OLD DOG and moves away, as he pumps his fist skyward, cur To: EXT. -— STATE BOXING COMMISSION'S OFFICE BUILDING - SUNSE The classical building is located in the center of the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIVE MEN sit along the length of an elevated row table like you would see at a senate hearing. ROCKY sits below them. On the front of the dais is the Pennsylvania State Boxing Commissions seal.

dialogues.speaker: COMMISSIONER
dialogues.text: The tests administered were much more sophisticated than when you were recommended to retire and so you've passed the mandatory state exam. But frankly, your age is still a big concern - And weighing in all the different factors and unpredictable elements that go along with this sport, we cannot in good conscience, recommend re-licensing at this time.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Didn’t I do what ya asked.

dialogues.speaker: COMMISSIONER
dialogues.text: Yes, but you understand, it’s your best interest we’re thinking of.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: But I did what ya asked, right?

dialogues.speaker: COMMISSIONER
dialogues.text: No one wants to be held accountable for a serious injury, or even a fatality.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: I appreciate that but, I passed them tests

dialogues.speaker: COMMISSIONER
dialogues.text: If we’re wavering on this he should at least redo all the testing.

dialogues.speaker: COMMISSIONER
dialogues.text: How will that indemnify us?

dialogues.speaker: COMMISSIONER
dialogues.text: I think we have to stand by our decision. It’s about moral accountability.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Ain't’ followin’ this.

dialogues.speaker: COMMISSIONER
dialogues.text: Your request for a license at this time is denied.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY-
dialogues.text: (at a loss) Yo...don’t I got some kind ‘of rights?

dialogues.speaker: COMMISSIONER
dialogues.text: Some “rights” may be open to interpretation. Which rights?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: ‘Rights’ like in the thing they wrote down the street.

dialogues.speaker: COMMISSIONER
dialogues.text: The Bill of Rights?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Yeah, them rights!

dialogues.speaker: COMMISSIONER
dialogues.text: What about them?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: They say somethin’ ‘bout pursuin’ happiness, right?

dialogues.speaker: COMMISSIONER
dialogues.text: Your point is?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: I'm pursuin’ somethin’ an’ nobody looks too happy about it.

dialogues.speaker: COMMISSIONER
dialogues.text: We’re only looking out for your interests.  62.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (hotter) Yeah, I appreciate it but I did what ya wanted me to do an’ more an’ that should do it, right? I know ya doin’ ya job very well, an’ that’s good, but why va gotta xight,’cause if somebody goes through all the junk ya gotta go through to get where they wanna get, let ‘em ~ Ain’t nobody got the right to stop ‘em ‘cause, maybe someday, some of you guys are gonna wake up ‘an wanna finish somethin’ ya never finished, ‘an ya paid ya dues. But ya told ‘no, forget it’ so ya never finished it. So who’s got the right to tell ya that, after ya done what ya was asked to do‘?! Nobody! None of you guys know what’s in the next guys heart!! Only that guy knows!"Ya gotta do what ya guts tell ya to do, if ya don’t, ya just takin’ up a seat until the next bums come along! Who’s supposed to live like that. So if I ain’t gettin’ my license, then gimme more of them tests. ‘Cause I ain’t leavin’ here without somethin’ that resembles what's right! The commissioners pause to consider.

dialogues.speaker: LUCKY BAR
dialogues.text: ANDY and several dried-up regulars crane their necks to the suspended TV.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: As promised earlier, a true classic from the ‘Truth is Stranger Than Fiction File” - Former Champion Rocky Balboa has reapplied to a license and believe it or not passed the test. The former slugger said he'll participate in small local contests - The STREET-TRASH GROUP that had the altercation with ROCKY, sit at the bar and hurl derisive comments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT. PAULIE SITS IN THE FOREMAN’S OFFICE reading a paper. A forty year-old Black foreman approaches PAULIE and they converse. RAVI is in the distant background. We can see from PAULIE’S body language, he has just received devastating news. He steps out and throws his helmet against the wall.
